Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: TYPE A Nano-Constriction Devices for Isolation and Cultivation of Environmental Microbes
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Northeastern University to develop a device whose purpose is to automatically isolate and cultivate new microbial species from the environment using recent advances in micro/nano-fabrication. Most bioactive compounds discovered to date have come from microbial sources. Yet over 99% of microbial biodiversity remains uncultivated using conventional laboratory approaches, and this pool is an enormous untapped source for bio-prospecting. The proposed work attempts to cultivate microbes in their own habitat, and employs an automated, high-throughput method. Applied at an appropriate scale, this method may be transformative for generating novel microbial biodiversity for industrial, ecological, and biomedical applications. This research will foster collaborations between engineers and biologists and prepare undergraduate and graduate students for dynamic multidisciplinary work environments. Hands on training in the laboratory will be provided for high school science teachers from Boston inner city schools to expose them to this and other emerging technologies.

The overarching goal of this project is to create a novel platform technology to cultivate microbial species that have remained elusive in traditional isolation and cultivation methods. The technique being developed is a radical departure from traditional methodologies, cultivating microorganisms will be cultivated in situ, which will automatically provide cells with the required growth factors. The key feature of the technology is a growth chamber with a single sub-micrometer opening to the outside environment. The effectiveness of this novel device will be demonstrated by isolating novel strains and species from marine and soil habitats using a set of prototype devices. The developed devices will be disseminated to the community by organizing and hosting a new conference on cultivating microorganisms at Northeastern University. The conference attendees will be trained to use the new devices and provided with prototype devices to test. The technology will be presented at microbiology meetings that potential users attend. A website will be created that will list the new species that are cultivated using this technology and will allow the scientific community to acquire the species for further investigations.

This award is being made jointly by two Programs- (1) Instrument Development for Biological Research, in the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Biological Sciences Directorate), and (2) Biotechnology, Biochemical and Biomass Engineering, in the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems (Engineering Directorate).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed a device whose purpose is to automatically isolate and cultivate new microbial species from the environment using recent advances in micro/nano-fabrication. The proposed research will directly benefit the microbiology and ecology communities by providing a new tool for studying bacterial in their natural environment. The device can also be used to selectively screen for bacterial species that could improve agriculture, bioremediation, chemical synthesis, and health.

The main evidence highlighting the need for this technology is that most bioactive compounds discovered to date came from microbial sources. Yet over 99% of microbial biodiversity remain uncultivated and therefore cannot be analyzed in a laboratory.  These “missing” microbial species represent arguably the largest unexplored pool of biological and chemical diversity on our planet.

So many bacteria remain undiscovered because of the phenomenon of microbial “uncultivability.” Obtaining live, pure cultures of “uncultivable” bacteria that can be analyzed in a laboratory is the oldest unresolved phenomenon in microbiology. The overarching goal of this proposal is to meet the challenge and create a novel platform technology that will provide a pipeline of new species from the “missing” microbial biodiversity.

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT:

Our approach is a radical departure from traditional methodologies. The latter are based on microbiologists’ ability to “guess” the unknown requirements of novel species and, if successful, grow and isolate them.  This conventional approach fails to cultivate the overwhelming majority of microbial species.  Our approach eliminates this guesswork.  We can now cultivate microorganisms in situ, in their own habitat, which automatically provides cells with the required growth factors: if they are present in nature, they are available to the species we want to grow.

The core of our approach is a growth chamber with a single sub-micrometer opening to the outside. The diameter of our constrictions is close to the size of individual bacterial cells, allowing only one cell to enter the constriction.  Once inside, proliferation of this cell blocks the entrance and prevents cells of other species from entering the growth chamber.  Growth inside of our chambers is primarily in the form of pure cultures. One wall of the growth chamber is from a chemically permeable membranes containing pores that are less than 100 nanometers in diameter. When incubated in situ, diffusion through the pores provides nutrients and chemical communication between the chamber and the native environment. Therefore, cells inside have access to the exact same suite of growth factors as their free-living counterparts.  If a population is growing in nature, its representatives are able to grow inside the chamber. Note that the proposed cultivation method does not require any knowledge of the target microbes’ nutritional requirements.

The effectiveness of this novel device has been demonstrated by isolating 103 bacterial samples from 168 isolation and growth chambers. The isolation efficiency and discovery of new microorganisms was similar to cultivation plates. There was little overlap of species between the two methods, which suggests that the isolation technique has an effect on bacteria selection. Importantly, far fewer steps were required to obtain results that are similar to standard plate methods. Based on these results and feedback from users, we have optimized the devices to be easier to use and to improve the isolation performance. We expect that the new iteration of devices will surpass methods currently in use. Testing of the new devices is ongoing.

 

BROADER IMPACTS:

Our approach is the first truly automated, high-throughput method that can be used anywhere on the planet to access species that are difficult or impossible to cultivate otherwise. Applied at an appropriate scale, this method has the potential resolve the phenomenon of microbial uncultivability, generating novel microbial biodiversity for industrial, ecological, and biomedical applications. The technology has been presented at national and international conferences, appeared in online media stories, and in peer-reviewed journal publications. An initial set of devices has been disseminated to the community. Multiple groups have contacted the project principal investigator and received free prototype devices for testing. We have created a simple guide for training new users on how to use the devices. A website is under development that will list the new species that are cultivated using this technology. This research has fostered collaborations between engineers and biologists and prepared undergraduate and graduate students for dynamic multidisciplinary work environments. Hands on training in the laboratory was provided for a high school science teacher, who is using his experience to expose them to this and other emerging technologies.
